This is fine if you like coffee but as we only like tea it was a bit annoying. Especially when we asked if we could get tea instead of the coffee. We were told that it would not be possible and we would have to pay for teabags from the minibar. This I thought was poor for a hotel like the waldorf. Other than that the hotel was very nice and would recommend it to anyone. All the staff were very helpful and friendly and the location was perfect. Also the bed in the room was the most comfortable in any hotel we have stayed in.

Reviews.Title: “Grand name, but mediocre experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Needing a room in Midtown for a business trip, I booked at the Waldorf because of my Hilton HHonors membership and my previous happy experience with the Millennium Hilton downtown. I can echo other posters' enthusiasm about the interior workmanship and decoration, though the path to the front desk from the street seems a little labrynthine. Disappointingly, the 3 "Zip-In Check-In" kioks were *all* down, so I had to wait patiently in a long line for the room key despite my expectations. The room was pretty much what one would expect for this class of hotel, with the exception of the peeling paint in the bathtub (noted by another reviewer as well). What were more disappointing were the absence of a bathrobe or evening turndown service. And in-room Internet access was $10/night, which is annoying nickel-and-diming for hotels of this tier. Finally, for all you business travelers, note that even on weekdays, the core clientele seems to be tank-topped tourists. I had to duck around several of them taking photographs of each other in the hallways and lobbies, presumably to send back to their aunts in Peoria. While I can't claim any truly critical shortcomings of my experience, neither did I feel that it met the standards for this class of hotel. If your business brings you to Midtown, you are better off booking at the Omni or the Inter-Continental.

Reviews.Title: “A grand hotel worth the stay!”
Reviews.Author: HeyYou18
Reviews.Content: Stayed here from 7/22 - 7/31/05 with my two sons, ages 12 and 14-1/2. Requested a room with 2 beds, away from the elevators, stairs, and ice machines. I also requested a corner room since I read on various message boards that corner rooms were slightly larger than others. I called the hotel to reconfirm my requests two days prior to arrival. I arrived at 10:00 pm via a limo/sedan service. We pulled up to the front entrance on Park Avenue but the doorman told us we had to go around the corner to the other entrance to drop off our luggage. The bellman took our luggage, gave us a ticket and told us to check in at the front desk and that they would deliver our luggage to our room. There was a short wait at the check-in desk but it went fairly quickly. The hotel ran out of the corner room with two beds that I had previously requested but did give me a corner room on the 15th floor with one bed. I asked the clerk if it would be possible to change rooms the following day and she said yes and that I should come back after 3:30 pm to check for availability. We proceeded to go up to the room until my son mentioned that he was really thirsty. The bellman walked us to the gift shop where we purchased our drinks. He said he would meet us up in our room with our luggage. When we arrived in our room, the bellman showed up shortly after that. After he dropped off our luggage, he took the liberty to go down the hall to fill our ice bucket for our drinks. Now, that's something I've never experienced before at another hotel! All was smooth sailing until I noticed and the bellman noticed that the coffee maker in our room was dirty (still had coffee in it) along with a half full dirty coffee cup. The bellman said he would report it to the front desk for me. About half an hour after the bellman left, no one had come to change out the dirty coffee pot or cup so I called the front desk myself. It took two phone calls that night and one phone call in the morning before I received my new coffee pot and new coffee cup. That, I found was unacceptable. Our room was good sized and seemed clean except for the coffee pot incident. It had a fairly large closet, one really comfortable bed with luxurious sheets, pillows and blankets, a desk with a chair and a fax machine. The room was big enough for me to use the air mattress that I had brought along (just in case we didn't get a room with two beds). The bathroom was also a good size. Full tub with shower, large sink, and plenty of floor space to move around. The following day we checked in at the front desk around 8:30 pm after our NY tour to request for the change of room with two beds. The clerk stated that they had held 4 corner rooms for us with two beds but when they went to collect our luggage to move into the new room, the luggage’s were not packed, therefore, they had given up our rooms to other guests. I told her that the clerk the night before did not mention that I had to pack my bags. I asked her if the other rooms with two beds were indeed smaller than the corner rooms and she said yes, they were a lot smaller. The clerk then excused herself and went and spoke with a manager. The manager came back and started checking something on the clerk's computer screen. While he was doing that, I told him in a kidding way that I wouldn't mind if he upgraded us to a suite. He replied and said he may be able to do something for me. The clerk came back and said that I got upgraded to a mini suite with two beds, a sitting room, and basically, a much larger and better room than the corner room I had originally requested. We packed up our old room and checked into our new 11th floor room. Upon arriving to the front door, I noticed we were right next to the ice machine. My first thought was, “oh no”, that's why this room was available but once we got into the room, we checked out the noise level from the ice machine from inside the room and it was tolerable since the only place where you could really hear the ice machine was in the toilet area. The entrance to the mini suite leads you into a roomy foyer. From there, you enter the main part of the room with two double beds, an armoire with a TV, a desk and the fax machine. To the left of the desk is a door that leads to a sitting room which had a reading lamp and single sofa, and a vanity area. From there, you walk through french swing doors that lead you to the marbled floor bathroom. The bathroom was large enough to fit two people comfortably. Bathroom amenities included Neutrogena shampoo, conditioner, lotions, soaps, and mouthwash. There was a separate air conditioning/heating system for the main room and one for the sitting room. The two closets were in the sitting room. We ended up using the air mattress in the sitting room for my older son since he wanted the privacy and we each ended up getting our own separate beds which was nice since it’s not too comfortable sharing a double size bed. The beds were really comfortable. The sheets and comforter were also really nice. I found the towels to be on the skimpy side considering the sheets and comforters were such high quality. There are at least 4 different entrances/exits to the hotel. The lobby on Park Avenue is the grandest. The lobby was always busy during the day and evening hours. A lot of people just relaxing on the sofas. I used the hotel’s safe deposit box everyday which was free of charge. I did not order room service as the prices were outrageous. I did not eat in any of the restaurants in the hotel either. The hotel is ideally situated to 5th Avenue and Madison Avenue shopping, Times Square, Grand Central Station and subway and bus lines. All was within walking distance. The #6 train stops half a block away from the hotel and the bus stop is also about half a block away. We purchased the 7-day Metrocard which was the best value for traveling around Manhattan for the 10 days we were there. We didn’t take the taxi at all since the subway and buses were so convenient and there were so many of them that the wait was really short. I preferred taking the buses since you could see the sites as you passed instead of being in the hot subway platforms and underground on the subway. For longer trips from one point to another, the subway is the way to go since it gets you there much faster. My MTA subway and bus map along with a laminated street map that I purchased online were invaluable. I didn’t get lost once during our stay! Check out was smooth and painless. It took less than a minute at the front desk. The ride to the airport on the other hand was a different story but I’ll save that for another message board. After I booked the Waldorf=Astoria I started reading the message boards and then started to worry that I had booked the wrong hotel since a lot of the posts were negative. To my relief, my stay was a splendid one except for the coffee pot incident but everything else about this hotel was fine. The decor was fine, the staff was friendly, the plumbing and air conditioning were fine. The grandeur and the history of the hotel is something special in itself. I wouldn't hestitate for a second to stay here again and would recommend it to friends and family too.

Reviews.Title: “You Have to stay here”
Reviews.Author: Travellhopper
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for the first time and were not dissapointed. This is a fantastic hotel that has class all over. The entrance is superb,the food and the rooms. A must hotel to stay at you will not be dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at the Waldorf”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Waldorf 3rd - 7th July 2005. We were given a very large corner room on the 14th floor and it was just what we'd expected of the Waldorf. The decor in the room was tasteful and in keeping with the rest of the hotel (the rest of the hotel being very plush from what we saw!) and the bed, although not the biggest, was the most comfy we had ever stayed in! On our first night they also bought us a bottle of champagne and strawberrys dipped in chocolate because we were on our honeymoon! You can't beat the location of the hotel either, it's in walking distance to just about everything. Overall an extremely pleasant stay and we would definitely recommend it to others.

Reviews.Title: “A Classic Deserving of Praise”
Reviews.Author: CajunWave
Reviews.Content: I was fortunate to stay at the Waldorf=Astoria on a discounted rate through one of the bidding sites. I could not have been more pleased. The hotel is stunning in so many ways. That art deco look and intricate tiling in the lobby took my breath away. Maurice at the front desk quickly and efficiently checked me in to room 632, which was quite small but very comfortable. I travelled solo so it was totally adequate. Everything worked very well in the room, although the internet access service via the TV leaves much to be desired and probably isn't worth the $10/day fee. Bring your laptop instead. I don't think the 6th floor has been remodeled very recently as the carpets were quite worn. Other floors have nicer carpet. Finally, if you fly into JFK, take the AirTrain! VERY EASY connection to the Waldorf. Train to Jamaica station, then the E subway. Five or six stops later, you're in Manhattan and at the Lexington/51 station...2 short blocks from the hotel! All for $7!

Reviews.Title: “Enchanting Bargain Priced Stay At Waldorf Astoria”
Reviews.Author: FHuggies
Reviews.Content: I low-balled on Priceline and ended up staying at the Waldorf. After reading some reviews here and elsewhere I was concerned about what we would be getting for our money...thoughts of the broom closet swept my mind. When I called the hotel before arriving to make sure I would be getting a room with 2 beds, instead of one King they were Not helpful and somewhat rude. "You get the room that Priceline has set aside". However, upon arrival, they were very accomodating. The room was nice, aged but that did add to the ambience of this old grande dame hotel. The bathroom was Very large , there was plenty of closet and storage space. The room had city views and was quiet for a Midtown location. The location is the best for a stay in NY. Service was excellent, the beds comfy, real china for your coffee an unbelievable lobby and all for $125 a night! Only complaint...the coffee in the room was awful! Just hope I can score another bargain for this hotel again!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Weekend At The Waldorf”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Ever since I saw the film, I have loved the idea of taking a weekend break at this famous hotel. When my husband surprised me with Broadway tickets for our anniversary, it seemed the perfect opportunity for our own “weekend at the Waldorf.” LOCATION Location....location...location....the Waldorf-Astoria is located on Park Avenue, between 49th and 50th streets. This location is very accessible by public transportation (Grand Central Terminal is just about 4-5 blocks down) and very handy to shopping, tourist attractions, theater district, etc. ARRIVAL I booked a Concierge Suite through the hotel website for $335/night. When we arrived at the Waldorf, I couldn’t stop staring at the beautiful Park Avenue lobby and the gorgeous “Wheel of Life” floor mosaic. We then went from that lobby into the wood-paneled Main Lobby. The centerpiece of this lobby was the very ornate historic clock. The contrast between the two lobbies was very interesting, with the Park Ave Lobby being very feminine and pastel, and the Main Lobby being very dark and masculine. We made our way over to the reception desk where the courteous reception clerk checked us in immediately. It was a few minutes after 2pm and there was no line. I had casually mentioned that it was our anniversary in the comments section of the online reservation form, and to our delighted surprise, the clerk informed us that he was upgrading us to a luxury suite in the Waldorf Towers! He then directed us to the private elevator for Towers gusts. It took me a moment to realize that you had to insert your room key into a reader for the elevator to move. ACCOMMODATIONS After a rapid ascent, my husband and I arrived on the 29th floor and quickly found our room number, 29M. The hallway was lovely, decorated in soft pastel shades and gilt chandeliers. We opened the door and I was amazed. Immediately I realized that this was no ordinary hotel suite. We entered into a marble-floored foyer and walked straight through to a sumptuous living room. I loved the serene color scheme of light blues and aqua. One end of the room held a gracious seating area with built-in bookcases. Several large windows, dressed with exquisite valences and drapes, offered views of Park Avenue. A large, gilt-edged mirror over a marble fireplace dominated the opposite end of the room. A second seating area contained three winged chairs, sofa and coffee table. A large antique desk held leather portfolios that contained embossed stationary, post cards, room service menus and other info. A matching stand held a combined printer/fax machine. The overall décor of the room gave the feel of being in an English country house. We walked back to the foyer and turned left into a small corridor which contained a large closet and a gorgeous green-marbled topped wet-bar that held a small refrigerator. My only complaint was that the mini-bar case took up most of the space inside, but we found enough room to house our own bottles of water, champagne, etc. From the corridor, we entered a nice-sized bedroom where the light aqua color scheme was accentuated by darker green and rust orange in the furniture and bedspread. The king-sized bed was very comfortable and the air conditioning system worked well enough that we were able to enjoy the wonderful Frette linen bedsheets and duvet. A dressing room/boudoir was next, with a dressing table and three large size floor-to ceiling mirrored closets that were large enough to hold full-length ballgowns. Inside were two luxurious Frette bathrobes that were heavenly to lounge about in. From the boudoir, we stepped into a large marble bathroom containing a deep, soaking tub, a separate shower and a large sink/vanity. The crowning touch was a lovely silver tray bearing posh Penhaligon English bath products and shampoo. The water temperature and pressure were excellent, both in the shower and the tub, and the fluffy towels provided made it a joy to dry off. A few minutes after we explored the suite, the doorbell rang and my husband opened it to find one of the hotel staff bearing a tray of petit-fours and strawberries, compliments of the hotel. I was very touched by the solicitous attention we were receiving. The goodies were absolutely delicious and I later found out (when we returned home and I looked up the price) that the level of suite to which we had been upgraded normally went from $739 to over a grand (depending on the time of year), per night. DINING The Waldorf offers quite a few options for dining. We were disappointed to learn at the time of check-in that the 4-star French restaurant, Peacock Alley was closed until November for renovations. We did enjoy a wonderful dinner and excellent cocktails at the Bull & Bear. Entree prices were in the $30-40 range, but we thoroughly enjoyed the “Angus Prime” steak and felt it deserved the hype. Other restaurants at the Waldorf currently include Oscars, the casual brasserie and Inagiku, a Japanese restaurant. We also took advantage of the Executive Lounge, which served continental breakfast and evening hors d’oeurves. The Lounge was pleasant and some of the food choices were very tasty such as the chicken with mango and black bean salsa. Soft drinks, coffee and tea were complimentary, but alas, alcoholic drinks are not complimentary. The Lounge was very graciously and comfortably furnished, but was a little on the small side and could get a bit crowded. On Sunday, we decided to be totally decadent and ordered breakfast through Room Service. This was very pricey, but it was a fabulous splurge. Our breakfast included a scrumptious spinach and tomato frittata, eggs & sausage, bakery basket of croissant and danish and freshly squeezed orange juice. This all arrived on a rolling cart, elegantly set with linen tablecloth and napkins, china, crystal glassware and the crowning luxury of a fragrant rose in a bud vase. Best of all, the food quickly arrived, piping hot and fresh. SERVICE Having read some of the reviews on this board, we were very pleased with the high level of service we received. I can honestly say that I felt the hotel lived up to the reputation of being the hotelier for presidents, kings, queens, ambassadors, etc, that it touts on its website. Whenever we encountered a staff member, even in the hallway, they wished us a pleasant good morning/evening. The housekeeper was cheerful and room service was very prompt and courteous. All in all, my husband and I have to give the Waldorf Astoria top marks for its overall service and value. One small drawback was the high charge for parking at $45.00 a day. We would have preferred to drive into the city, but we felt that this cost was excessive, especially given that we were guests at the hotel. Apart from that point, however, we were extremely pleased with our stay.

Reviews.Title: “Beauty only skin deep”
Reviews.Author: NC_Hiker
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Waldorf (room 1424) during a meeting held there. Our airport car dropped us off at the motor entrance, sort of a "tunnel" in the middle of the hotel on the ground floor. There was luggage everywhere chained to racks. There was no staff to assist us with our luggage so we followed the signs to the lobby. The lobby and all the public areas are simply wonderful. The workmanship of craftsmen from times past really makes an impression. And impressed we were - until we arrived at our room. The standard rooms are small and have ancient heating / a/c units which are difficult to set to get a comfortable temperature. While the furnishings seemed to be in good shape, the basic room was not. Peeling paint and damaged woodwork were very noticeable. The bathroom was in poor shape. The tub had been refinished at some time in the past and the "new" coating was now peeling off in large sheets to expose the original surface. The fiberglass sink had also been painted over and black cracks were appearing for several inches in all directions around the drain. It was not at all what I expected of the Hilton "flagship". We had dinner at Oscars - two appetizers, a sandwich and a fish dish. The bill was just over $60 which seemed a bit much for what we had. The next night we ate at the Bull and Bear where we both had filets. I can't recommend the restaurants given the fact there is much better food available outside the hotel. On checkout I gave the bellman our luggage to store for 2 hours while we did checked out the sights. When we returned and went to the luggage storage area we found luggage stacked everywhere outside and down the hallway. They had no idea where our luggage was but after searching the hallway we found 3 of the 4 bags - unsecured. The fourth bag was harder to find - they gave up looking but we finally located it under another bag some distance away. I recommend if you want to see the Waldorf, stay somewhere else and stop by the Waldorf to tour the public areas - that way you might avoid a poorly maintained room like ours.

Reviews.Title: “beautiful hotel,but very hot”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: my husband and i took our 2 nephews to new york for 4 nights,i bid for my hotel and was given the waldorf astoria.i was very pleased that we would be staying there since i had heard so much about it.the hotel is very beautiful,very easy check-in.our room was very nice,but,not comfortable.first of all,there are only double beds,very hard to adapt to when most hotels of this caliber now have queen beds.the room was very hot when we entered so i pulled the shades and turned the ac on high.we left and went to dinner,came back about 3 hours later and the room was still hot.i called maintance,he arrived quickly and said the ac was working properly and that he would ask the manager to call us.the manager called and said the "problem"would be taken care of the next day.i assumed maybe that we would be moved to another room but no one ever contacted us again during our stay.we ended up having to remove all bed covering except for 1 sheet and still could not sleep comfortably.if you are looking for a beautiful hotel only you should stay here but if you like to sleep in a comfortable room please look elsewhere

Reviews.Title: “Impeccable in all Aspects”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: INTRODUCTION: I will only speak words of unmistakeable praise for the incomparable Waldorf=Astoria. Situated in a prominent and convenient New York City location, it is an expansive building that rises to forty-two stories when the opulent Waldorf Towers are included. No aspect of my stay could be improved, except for minor details that are not worth remembering. I will outline each experience and why it was enjoyed. PRIOR TO ARRIVAL Since my flight out of Canada was delayed until the next morning due to electrical storms above LaGuardia airport, the Waldorf=Astoria graciously agreed to hold our extensive suite for check-in the next morning. ARRIVAL AND CHECK IN Driven in by my our limousine driver from the LaGuardia Airport to the somewhat narrow motor entrance, we were promptly greeted courteously by Waldorf=Astoria staff who immediately took our luggage and stored it until we had checked in. We walked up to the reception area, what I would dub the second lobby, where elaborate armchairs and sofas await weary travelers. A historical clock graces the centre of the lobby and chimes hourly. One knows that they are already immersed in this hotel's spectacular history. Check-in is efficient and personable, and luggage is carried to the room separately but arrives promptly. ROOM I would have to consider the two-bedroom and two-bathroom suite at the Waldorf=Astoria the most sumptuous in which I have ever stayed. Upon opening the double door with the stainless steel handle, we were greeted with a feast for the eyes: a beautiful checked floor in the foyer that led to other beautifully decorated and furnished rooms. i. FOYER The foyer, as mentioned, included a tasteful chessboard style floor. A bench sat against the wall; a table against the other. At the right of the entrance, there was a bar: complete with glasses, a sink, and two refrigerators. The refrigerator was useful for freezing water, as the weather in New York City was very hot over the duration of the stay. ii. MASTER BEDROOM The master bedroom, with striped white and yellow wallpaper, included a four poster bed as well as much storage space. The storage space included a walk in closet with a bolted safe, and two dressers. There was also a large television for the use of guests. iii. DRESSING ROOM With even more closet space, a large mirror, and a make-up table, this room was very useful for us. It also had a very relaxing and comfortable chair beside a telephone table which was useful for placing calls. iv. MASTER BATH The master bathroom was equally as, if not more, exceptional that all of the other rooms. The same chessboard floor as in the foyer was a prominent feature, as well as a separate toilet room with a telephone and two sinks. There was also a bath and separate shower, which had a wide range of temperatures for water. Lighting is very divided in the bathroom which is useful for environmental purposes. v. SECOND BEDROOM The second bedroom, which was an attachment to the Suite, was smaller but equally embellished. It held a Queen sized bed and ample closet space. It led to a second bathroom, which was simple but large enough in which to function. vi. LIVING ROOM I would have liked to spend my entire stay in this room, admiring the tasteful furniture and elaborate finishings. There was a small collection of books that would have been a pleasure to peruse. For business travelers in New York City, there was a desk with personal facsimile machine and lovely Waldorf=Astoria stationery and postcards that I was pleased to use. It was also a fine place to eat breakfast for in-room dining. GENERAL STAFF ATTITUDES DURING STAY These were always positive. We were always greeted by maids, bellmen, and chefs alike in a courteous manner. The traffic director at the front of the hotel did all in his power to flag down taxis for Waldorf=Astoria guests, which was a recognisably difficult task. A staff member even welcomed us into the Grand Ballroom, which was being prepared for a special function, to see it. This was a true portrayal of the standard of service under which this grand hotel operates. PROXIMITY TO ATTRACTIONS Located at the corner of Park Avenue and 50th Street, the location cannot be beaten. While it is away from the bustle and even danger of Wall Street and Ground Zero, it is in great propinquity to attractions such as the Rockefeller Center. It is also only a block away from St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church and others such as St. Thomas's. It is only a short walk to dining (if one is not enjoying the dining that the hotel has to offer) and the theatre district. (Taking a taxi to the theatre is a waste of time due to the wait at that time of day.) The hotel is also quite near to famous stores such as Saks Fifth Avenue and Pink, but I recommend a taxi to major department stores such as Macy*s or Bloomingdale's. BUSINESS CENTER This is the only place where I find fault in the Waldorf=Astoria, for a very small reason. I had to receive a facsimile from my office during the stay, and the fee for receiving the fairly thick facsimile was over $50. While I found our room to be somewhat of a bargain, I was flabbergasted at this price. However, the Business Center conveniently took my postcards and letters to put in the US Mail. DINING There are three restaurants in the hotel of diverse natures: the casual Oscar's, the fine dining steakhouse The Bull and Bear, and Inagiku, which markets its fine Japanese cuisine. The hotel also boasts a plethora of fine bars and lounges. Personally, I only ate one dinner and two breakfasts at Oscar's, and left the hotel premises for other enjoyable meals (such as at District or San Pietro - all my sincere recommendations). All meals, though not inexpensive, were thoroughly enjoyable. We also enjoyed cocktails in the hotel's lobby while enjoying the live pianist who plays exceptionally and watching the comings and goings of guests. It is certainly a very upbeat lobby. CHECK-OUT AND DEPARTURE With a commitment that lasted until 1245 on Sunday afternoon, we would not be able to meet the standard check out time of 1200. Therefore, Guest Services kindly extended our stay to 130 PM free of charge. When we finally did check out, it was done in a very professional yet friendly manner. We were advised to, because we enjoyed the suite so much, return and request the same room. We certainly will. Since our flight was not until the evening, the hotel stored our baggage for the balance of the afternoon. OTHER REMARKS i. Elevators Elevators at the Waldorf=Astoria are rather small and rarely private. Six elevators with usually only five working tends not be enough, but there are never waits that are too extensive. ii. History The hotel was first opened in 1893 by the wealthy William Waldorf Astor, at the site of his former grand residence at the corner of Fifth Avenue at 33rd Street. The = symbol in the Waldorf=Astoria was born when the Astoria Hotel was built and linked with a corridor. Both buildings were razed in 1929 for the Empire State Building, and the next Waldorf=Astoria was erected in 1930 and 1931. Further information regarding history can be found on the hotel's website, (---). In conclusion, the Waldorf=Astoria has a refined group of staff members everywhere to the business center to the maids, is in a pristine location, and boasts great history and décor. I feel obliged to recommend this exceptional property to anyone who enjoys a feel of history and opulence where they stay.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was my first stay in NYC and I was told that I must stay at the Waldorf Astoria. It was the New Year's Eve weekend and I expected the hotel staff to be busy. The only complaint I had at first arrival was the check in. I requested early check in and arrived around 2pm as expected. After waiting in a line for 30 minites, waiting for one of 8 desk receptions to check me in, I was told that my room was not ready and to return in an hour. I decided to look around the area for the hour and then returned to the hotel. Once I returned, I was told to wait an additional hour due to the maid service not being done cleaning the room. Again, I went out for a walk to admire the area. This check in process happened one more time and by 6:30pm I was finally able to go to my room. Needless to say, I was not too happy after a long trip to NY having to wait for nearly 5 hours outside looking for entertainment to occupy my time. The lobby was very nice and large. Elevators were nicely decorated. Hallways were clean and large to move around. Entrance to my suite was impressive with the doorbell and old style door handles. The room was very large with plenty of room, over 450 sqf.. The living room had nice furniture with bar area etc. Bedroom was spacious with beautiful and comfortable bed. Bathroom was very nice and clean. One complaint about bathroom was that the toilet was running the entire stay at the hotel but I did not make the complaint to the front desk to ask that it be fixed, so dont judge that. Noise level from the street was low but the fans from the rooftop was somewhat annoying with the windows open. Not a big deal. Food prices for room service was way too expensive, even for this style hotel. The average for one person to have a nice breakfast in the room is between $20 - $35. I suggest leaving the room before 9am and going outside to one of many little deli's. They serve hot and cold breakfasts for less than $5 a person. That includes, two eggs, bacon, toast, and coffee or juice. I did not eat lunch or dinner at the hotel and chose to eat at the deli's enjoyng tastes that you can only get in NYC. The close attractions are nice. The Waldorf Astoria is close to Central Park and Times Square. If you want to watch the ball drop, which I did with my Fiance, I suggest leaving very early around 3 or 4pm. The streets close off quickly. Thankfully, I was able to get to 7th Ave and 44th St and had a great view.

Reviews.Title: “Shabby Chic”
Reviews.Author: pilipala9
Reviews.Content: We got an extremely good deal to stay at the Waldorf during Thanksgiving time, when both the hotel and the city were decorated beautifully. The lobby and reception area is very plush, whereas our room was more shabby chic, decadent even. I would not pay the full price to stay at this particular hotel because I think the price reflects the stature and fame of the hotel rather than actual service etc. But nonetheless, it was an experience to savour. And people always raise their eyebrows when you tell them you've stayed at the Waldorf!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Stay in the Waldorf!”
Reviews.Author: tobyteabag
Reviews.Content: Hi! My friend and I were a little concerned about having booked to stay in the Waldorf after having read some dodgy reports of the rooms on Trip Advisor, but I have to say the room was large and very well furnished, the bathroom was lovely and the whole experience of the hotel was wonderful, especially the services of the concierge who found us an amazing italian restaurant with very little notice - Bellinis, if you need to know! - The only fly in the ointment was that they managed to charge us twice for the room bill after we had departed and our e mails regarding this were ignored, in the end we had to phone the states to get it sorted out, but all is well now. If you are planning a short break in New York, then do consider this hotel as we were very happy with it, and the Tiramisu martinis in Harry's bar! Also, book the Grayline buses as they are a total bargain for a two day hop on and off ticket!

Reviews.Title: “This Is No Luxury Hotel, Hilton should be ashamed”
Reviews.Author: JasonFromCalifornia
Reviews.Content: The beautiful lobby and public areas of this hotel are much to nice for the rooms. I have stayed at this hotel many times both in the main hotel and the Towers, and every time have had major problems. Things ranging from finding puke on a wall at check in to having a bathroom with no power in for the length of stay. They have even "been kind enough" to invite me back for future stays as a result of the problem. Even on these return stays, I received rooms in just a bad of a condition as the previous rooms. The one thing I will say that is great about this hotel is the room service and the hotel operators. It amazes me that this hotel is able to get a way with charging so much money.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Experience”
Reviews.Author: SBAdvisor
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful 4 night stay at the Waldorf. Yes this hotel is old, but that is what makes it so special. If you want glitzy and brand new then try some place else. The history and art deco furnishings make this a stand out and the location is superb. Like any hotel the room location can make a difference. When we checked in they put us in room 802 which overlooked a lower rooftop and noisy air conditioning units. We called down and asked to be moved to a better location. They were booked that night but said they would move us the next day and to simply to leave our bags by the door and they would have everything moved for us. The next day we where moved as promised to a wonderful corner room on the 13th floor (room 1313). They even called to make sure that we were satisfied with our new room. The room was large, quiet and very comfortable. I loved that the windows opened to let in fresh air. All the staff members we dealt with were professional and helpful. The only in-hotel dining we had was breakfast at Oscars since that was complimentary for Hilton Honors VIP Gold guests. I always prefer to get out and eat where the locals eat and in NYC there are countless amazing choices. We loved our experience at the Waldorf and look forward to returning.

Reviews.Title: “Great old dame!”
Reviews.Author: married∈love
Reviews.Content: After being disspointed by our booked hotel (see 70 Park Ave. hotel review "Checked in then out") we booked a luxury suite here not knowing what to expect, only that we would have lots of room & luxury as promised. Well, after doing the tourist thing all day we finally checked in at 9pm & when questioned our rooms lower floor status, the 7th, decided to trust the front desk when they told us "We will be really surprised if you arent happy with this room." Well, for once they were right & we were pretty shocked to see what $600. a night at the Waldorf buys. We had; 1 large living room, (the kind you see in much older homes, a very large bedroom (LARGE!), a dressing room, a marble bathroom with 2 seperate sinks, a large tub & a seperate tiled in shower all surrounded by black marble & of course 2 comfy terry robes waiting in our large, formal, mirrored closets, just off the bathroom. We also had a full size kitchen (yes, a bit old & funky, but a kitchen!) with a small fridge & even a stove if you decide to whip up some omlettes or something. This is all off the wood floored foyer & thick, wooden (no cheapy things these) double doors. Now if you like comtemporary, this will not suit you at all as you will have to put up with a few portraits of presidents, antiques, & some sour looking others who I would have rather not watch me sleep, but then could always be retired to a drawer. The Audubon print above the bed made me feel right at home here & the room service was impeccable. We ordered a cheese plate for 2 (not on the menu) & got what looked like something out of Dean & Delucca's cheese department in double quick time...WOW!

Reviews.Title: “Art Deco Masterpiece”
Reviews.Author: NYCFrank
Reviews.Content: Walking into the Waldorf=Astoria (the "=" represents the Peacock Alley bridge that connected the Waldorf and Astoria hotels on the site now occupied by the Empire State Building.) transports you back to the Grand hotels of the 1930's. Everywhere you look, you're overwhelmed by another Art Deco masterpiece. We booked 2 rooms, an Executive Room and a Luxury Suite. Both rooms were corner rooms, fully renovated and had both fax machines and TV internet access. The furnishings, including Frette linens are top of the line, elegant and plush. The bathrooms have been fully renovated in the Art Deco style. If you want to treat yourself or someone else to a grand experience, book a luxury suite. They face Park Avenue, with 800 square feet of pure luxury. You enter a marble foyer with wet and mini bars. The bedroom is large by any standard, while the bathroom / dressing area are comparable in size to a New York studio apartment. The living room is gigantic, with fireplace, library and plush Federalist furnishings. Service throughout the hotel is top notch, and while expensive, breakfast/brunch at Oscars are a pleasure. You won't go wrong with the Waldorf if you steer clear of the lower end unrenovated rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Room reminds me of an old lady's "parlor"”
Reviews.Author: shoredude1971
Reviews.Content: Even by New York standards, the room was on the small side. But the room did have one definite advantage. The windows actually open. I'm always surprised by what people expect in a view in New York. I had a nice view of Park Avenue and 49th Street, but not some expansive view like others may believe exists. Pulling in, the doorman gave me a claim check for my bags. I went to check-in, where I had a very pleasant check-in. The desk clerk gave my claim check to the bellman who brough my bags upto the room. A very quick, efficient, and pleasant check-in experience. As for the room, think old lady. It was very elegant but not modern. So if you're looking for something that looks modern, this will not be it. The lobby is extremely gorgeous and elegant and so are many of the shops that are on the lobby level. Room service was overpriced, even by New York standards. Breakfast for one was $35. At many New York hotels, it is in the $20-$25 range. The subway is only a half block up Lexington Avenue. The hotel is very convenient to get around the city, but not by car. The cabbies on Park Avenue in front of the hotel swarmed no matter what time of day. I might stay here again if the price is right. It is definitely nicer than the New York Hilton (which I didn't like at all). But with so many hotels to choose from in I'd probably choose something else.

Reviews.Title: “Highlight of our NYC trip by FAR!”
Reviews.Author: 10DogMom
Reviews.Content: Just finished our first trip to NYC. This was a trip for my husband, so we included a Yankees game, a trip to see the U.S.S. Growler (sub), a meal at Sparks and the Sopranos tour... but seeing Chamber Magic, at the Waldorf, was so far and away the highlight of our trip, I had to write a review. (This was a surprise for him and I was not expecting to like it very much.) Our day was over-filled, so we were both a little grumpy as we rushed to get dressed up (suit and pant suit) and make our way to the Waldorf (our day had started by getting on the wrong subway line and riding to 205th when we wanted to go to 81st, so it just hadn't been a good day at all). I had also mis-remembered the starting time of this performance, and we had rushed extra hard unneccessarily. SIGH. So, my husband was testy about not knowing why he was all dressed up and why we were then waiting for 30 minutes. But as soon as he got into the suite and realized what was up... And as soon as the performance started, I was completely captivated, as well. Steve Cohen managed to amaze me with each and every "trick" he performed. Card tricks began and closed the show, but the incredible "enchantments" between caused gasps, "no way"s, and laughter at every turn. Almost as enjoyable as his performance was the disbelieving tone in each audience member who participated in the trick. The hour and a quarter passed far too quickly, and we are eagerly awaiting Mr Cohen's book tour when he will be performing nearer our home town - we're planning on being there! You can get tickets at (commercial URL). Do NOT leave this out of your trip to NYC!

Reviews.Title: “Splendid Stay at the Waldorf=Astoria”
Reviews.Author: Roadwise
Reviews.Content: My husband and I enjoyed a wonderful five night stay at the Waldorf=Astoria at the beginning of May. The staff took excellent care of us from check-in through our departure. Our room was spacious and elegant. A lovely dressing room (with sitting area, vanity and double closets) led to a beautiful Art Deco marble bath. The bed and linens were luxurious. All the rooms in the hotel include a personal fax/printer which proved handy during our stay. The location of the hotel was very convenient for the theater, shopping and the subway. It was a delight to walk through the magnificant lobby each time we returned to the hotel. We can highly recommend this property.

Reviews.Title: “Waldorf, okay”
Reviews.Author: jan40
Reviews.Content: I stayed here recently for 3 nights... this hotel is beautiful, however i found that everything in there was quite old and dare i even say a little tatty... we paid 600.00 dollars a night for a small suite, and even though it was a large space, the furniture was well used and i think for that sort of money it should be perfect...... checking in was a nightmare and the staff didnt smile so much, but overall, had a good stay, but would probably go for something a little more modern next time.

Reviews.Title: “Old School Elegance”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: What charm and elegance. Have you ever danced with your sweetheart as the Cole Porter grand piano was playing? Have you ever paused to steal a kiss from your sweetie in an exquisite lobby housing a flower arrangement as big as her heart? Have you had the opportunity to toast to your love in the lovely surroundings of the Bull and Bear? The Waldorf is all of this and more. The mini-suite is so expansive that my darling, jokingly, said to me, "This is so large, it's for people who don't want to be near each other." Of course, with room service, you can snuggle on the couch in the sitting room as you sip wine and talk over the next day's adventures at the theatre. Yes, the elevator was a bit noisy, but we will ask for a suite away from that bad boy on our next visit. After all, we did not finish our romantic dance next to Mr. Porter's piano.

Reviews.Title: “Just Fair”
Reviews.Author: RTR6
Reviews.Content: Check-in was great. Fast and efficient. Lobby is beautiful, so are the shops. The room was small, cramped and showed its age. The bellman at check-in were non existant, and finally took our bags out of the car after about a 5-7 minute wait. Getting the car was worse. It took 45 minutes after I called down for them to get my vehicle. And of course the cost was $45.00 a day. If this hotel did not have the name Waldorf Astoria, I do not thing it could survive in the NYC market. Stay at the New York Hilton on 53rd and sixth ave.

Reviews.Title: “Ground Floor Excellent - Rooms Tired”
Reviews.Author: lazyoaf
Reviews.Content: Went in August 2004 for 3 nights. Blown away by the Doorman, Lobby and the whole of the opulent groundfloor. Exactly what you expected it would be. Door staff hold umbrellas if its raining and all that stuff. Easy walk to most things and cabs everywhere for the lazy !! BUT (and its a big BUT) the rooms and hallways to the rooms are in desperate need of a refurb in some parts. Dissapointing after the impression from outside and that groundfloor. Staff were excellent except the Maintenance side, we reported a non-working toilet 3 X in those 3 days and they didnt manage to fix it at all. Filled out a complaint card and 6 months later still nothing. 1 night is an experience I can recommend, but theres better for the money

Reviews.Title: “Trading on past glories”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a weekend in NYC where we stayed at the Waldorf. First, the plus points: the location is fantastic, service was uniformly excellent. Location: you can't beat being walking distance from the theatres, central park and the subway. I had kids with me, and this is a big plus, becuase it means that whenever you take them out, it doesn't take long to get to where the fun starts. Service: Some 'grand' hotels have staff who fawn over you, which I can't stand; or they go to the other extreme and treat guests with cold contempt. The W=A staff got it just right. Now the negatives. The room was clean, and comfortable, but small and dowdy. Imagine staying at Grandma's house; it's OK, if a bit chintzy, but there's a lingering sense of damp mustiness. Oh and the bathroom badly needs remodeling. My room had the vanity unit cupboard doors sealed against damp with masking tape, and rust rings around the faucets. Strange people in the bull and bear: there were two high-class ladies, um, 'advertising their trade' in the bull and bear. Nothing overtly raunchy going on, of course -- these were upscale pros-- but I've been on enough business trips to know it when I see it.

Reviews.Title: “Sophisticated and Elegant”
Reviews.Author: Tor0110
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have just returned from our first visit to New York having stayed at the Waldorf Astoria from 16 - 23 April. After having read some of the reviews on this website I was dubious about our decision to stay there. We had always intended to stay at the Waldorf when we visited New York so we went ahead and booked. We arrived at about 12:30 on Saturday and was concerned as check-in is normally 3pm but the very pleasant check-in staff informed us our room was ready on arrival. We were on the 15th floor overlooking Park Avenue. What a room !! Very spacious and classy in decoration with 2 double beds, a seating area, desk, huge wardrobe, seperate dressing area and large bathroom. Beds were extremely comfortable and linen was fresh and new. Maid service was very efficient, sometimes coming in 3 times to replace towels etc, also our baggage was brought to our room within 5 minutes. Traffic was sometimes noisy but what do you expect in the city that never sleeps. I must recommend the Bull and Bear Steak restaurant, we enjoyed a fantastic meal in here, food and service were both excellent. We have had a marvellous time in New York and specifically at the Waldorf, I can't recommend it highly enough. I would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I recently spent a few days before my birthday at the Waldorf and had an absolutely wonderful time. With the possible exception of a good book, these wonderful old historic buildings like nothing else I know, have an almost magical ability to transport you back to a time long gone by. In its many years as one of the world’s most beautiful and recognized landmarks, the Waldorf has maintained a graceful elegance that no other hotel can surpass. I will never forget how exciting it was as we arrived at the famous Park Avenue entrance. The lobby was grand; it was bright and bustling with travelers and luxuriant. The staff was exceptional. Our suite was spacious, pleasantly decorated, comfortable and HUGE. Yes, the restaurants and room service were very expensive – which was completely expected. And, I can’t speak for every item on the menu, but everything I ordered was very good. My hope was to experience this marvelous old hotel in the heart of the greatest city on earth as it really is. I am happy to say that I was not disappointed in the least and my birthday trip to the Waldorf will remain one of the most memorable and unique travel experiences of my life.

Reviews.Title: “Above average”
Reviews.Author: misomeow
Reviews.Content: I have been to New York numerous times but this was the first time I went to the Waldorf. Me and my mom went for 3 nights. There were only two problems. The building is beautiful, as are the restaurants and of course the lobby and entrances. The people at the desks were so friendly and moved quickly. Our bags were sent up to our room. There was a little mix up so they made it up to us with an upgrade. It was fantastic! We were spoiled: We had a mini suite with two double beds with an amazing view right over Park avenue. Everything was gold and red. Very high ceilings with elegant moldings all around. A very hidden safety deposit box, large tv, armoire. We had french doors into a parlor where we both had our own closets and robes. Also coffee, mini bar, refrigerator, vanity. The bathroom was very spacious and also had those high ceilings. Nice deep bath tub, marble floors, plenty of extra gifts, nice big mirror over counter/sink... We were very satisfied. The bellmen, maids, and all other employees were very kind and helpful if we needed anything. The spa was amazing, as was the hair salon. The whole scene was gorgeous. We got facials and massages. They were pricey, but what can you expect? I thought it was worth it. The first problem was one of the concierges that was always there. My mom and I asked about what is around in the nightlife. He gave us about three recomendations, all of which were bad and he didn't understand what we were asking. So don't even bother with him, not very smart. (He also can't spell!) The second problem was that we scheduled afternoon tea. And double checked it an hour in advance. When we got there, there were cameras because we found out they were filming something or doing an interview. After asking many people we found out that there would be no afternoon tea. Even though we had already called and no one said it had been cancelled. We just went to the Plaza instead. Which was very nice (but that's for another review) As for the cleanliness... Me and my mom are fanatics about that. As for the other reviews I wouldn't accuse them of lying, maybe just exagerating, or they could have just had bad rooms. But in our experince everything was very clean. The bathrooms were spotless and the curtains and beds looked vintage (which is the whole hotel theme. I tend to like it) but had no marks or shredding what so ever. Well I hope this helps at least a few people. Good luck!

Reviews.Title: “Don't waste your money staying here, sad to say”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We have stayed at the Waldorf about six times over the past decade. Our last visit in April of this year will certainly be our very last. (I believe the Waldorf is scheduled to be turned into a condominium facility sometime in the near future.) While service was somewhat gracious, the rooms are so antiquated, outdated and so very small that it is not worth staying there. Our bathroom was miniscule; it was so small that I literally hit my head on the sink while reaching down to pick up a wet towel from the floor. There is barely enough room even to turn around comfortably in the bathroom. The bedroom itself was small with a horrible view (even though we had booked directly with the hotel), the bedding and linens are old, reeked of mildew, dirty, frayed and extremely heavy and hard to move around the room. While its location is wonderful for our needs, I think I will check out several of the newer boutique hotels in NYC next time; I would not recommend the Waldorf Astoria for any future travelers to the Big Apple; instead, stay somewhere decent and enjoy high or low tea at the Waldorf (assuming they will still offer it!), admire the lobby, and go back to sleep in a clean, decently sized room. A big thumbs down to the Waldorf, sad to say.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed on 17th Floor, beds that were so comfortable we didn't want to get out! Ok, so the view was naff but who goes to NY to look out of hotel windows. Nothing was too much trouble for any of the staff, Concierge service excellent, booked us 2 restaurants and both were excellent. The staff are all friendly and there is nothing pretentious about the Waldorf. The decor downstairs is beautiful, the huge flower arrangement in the lobby smells lovely. Maybe some of the decor upstairs could do with some tender loving care but staying here is an experience not to be missed. The location is ideal for shopping and sightseeing and there are some great restaurants nearby, try Bellini E52nd St for dinner, broadway diner(Lexington/E52nd) for breakfast or Cafe Oxford (opposite) for a different breakfast experience.

Reviews.Title: “Anti-climatical dissapointment”
Reviews.Author: Deon46
Reviews.Content: We took a well deserved break to the USA & Canada in December 2004 and as both my wife and I love going to New York City, we thought we would spoil ourselves by booking our stay at the Waldorf Astoria for the 6 days we were to visit the Big Apple. I specifically made arrangments for an early check in because our flight from South Africa arrived at JFK around 07:00. No sign of any early check in arrangements and only after getting into a heated argument with the manager explaining to him that we just had a 16 hour flight and he reluctantly made a plan for us. But this is where our dissapointment really started. Our room was located in the Waldorf Towers and upon entering the room it was clear to me that the accommodation may have been of a really good standard 50 years ago. The ice macine in the room was completed frosted over and to spite numerous requests this was never attended to. The bathroom seemed very tatty and it was clear that maintenance here was not high on the priority list. Besides having some of our belongigns stolen in the pub downstairs the whole trip was really not a memorable one besides now having the bragging rights to say that we satyed at the Waldorf but sad to say we wont be back.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely location outdated rooms”
Reviews.Author: Familybreaks
Reviews.Content: We stayed at The Waldorf for a week with our our two children. Although we were told we could check in at 2pm we had to wait until 3.30pm as the room was not ready even though our daughter had been travel sick and needed to change and wash. We were told that we could use the gym area to do this which we had no choice but to do as they would not budge on letting us have our room on time. Our room was on the 13th floor and not on the noisy side but the heater/airconditioning system did not work and as it was cold when we first got into the room they offered us a free standing heater as "the heating is not switched on in April!" Later in the week it was boiling hot but the air conditioning did not work so goodness knows what the excuse would be for that! The bathroom needing refurbishing and the plumbing for the room next door might as well been in our room for the noise we heard through the wall. Saying all that the location is perfect for sightseeing, the communal areas beautiful and the Bull and Bear restaurant in which we only ate one night was excellent in both food and service. We found the staff to be knowledgeable and helpful. All in all we would go back but to an upgraded room. Our tip for breakfast is the Broadway diner on Lexington about two blocks from the hotel. Lovely clean and airy diner, good food and service and great prices.

Reviews.Title: “not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed for 2 nights in April. I am a Hilton Honors gold card so was expecting some of the usual benefits re room upgrades. Upon arrival we were told we were upgraded to an Executive Room - on the 8th floor. Whilst the reception and ground floors areas are stunning - the accomodation floors looked very tired but we hoped that the rooms would not follow this theme. On opening our door there was a very strong smell of smoke (this was a non smoking room) also the room was tiny and looked very old fashioned ( yes I know this is an authentic hotel but there is a difference between authentic and Tatty. ) The good news is that they moved us to another room on the 6th Floor. By New York standards this was a good size with a dressing area and bathroom - but it still looked dull, the bathroom cabinet was broken, and the lack of decent double glazing was apparent as we thought the windows were open!!. I had high expectations of staying in this landmark hotel but at $411 (with taxes) they were not met. Friend of ours were staying nearer Time square for half the price and we met them for drinks in their hotel. In fact I was embarrassed to let them see our room. Like others on this sight I had read very mixed views on this hotel but assumed with the Gold card we would be luckier than others. We were not I am also a Platinum Starwood holder and as I stay in Hotels about 80 nights per year - mainly in North America this is certainly the worst case of value for money - I wish I had stayed in the Westin in Times Square - As the owners of this Hotel, Hilton need to spend some time and money restoring the bedrooms to a more acceptable level.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Old World New York!”
Reviews.Author: berksmom
Reviews.Content: My husband and I took a wonderful trip to NYC for our 5th Wedding Anniversary this past Christmas, and stayed at the Waldorf...could not ask for a better hotel! If you are looking for modern decor and a "trendy" new hotel, then this is NOT the place for you! However, if you desire beautiful classic New York style and customer service that goes above and beyond anything you can imagine (like letting me use one of the personal office computers after the computer center had closed, when I realized I needed a confirmation number from my email for a performance we were attending that evening), then this IS the place for you! Vindome, the concierge, is beyond wonderful...he can get you reservations to the busiest restaurant in town at a moment's notice. No, the rooms are not huge...but this is NYC! It's not known for it's "roominess"! The rooms are classically elegant, and the bed was just divinely comfortable! Have a great trip!

Reviews.Title: “An absolute Classic”
Reviews.Author: PradaP
Reviews.Content: This hotel was spectacular, especially the decor in the lobby, reception area (if you can call the magnificent hall that), the restaurants, and even inside the lifts. There were hundreds of very friendly staff on hand all the time, and all staff we came across in the lifts and corridors said a cheery "Have a good day" (!) The room was small, but well appointed, and had an interesting view of NYC. Two things that struck me as odd about this hotel, were that it did not have a swimming pool, and that everything extra seemed to cost money - Coffee and tea in the room were $4.50! Otherwise it was fantastic, and well worth a visit just to experience it. In fact i cannot imagine staying anywhere else in NYC now, although next time i would consider getting a suite of a deluxe room on a higher level. I think it would be hard to find a hotel in the world to rival the service and general experience offered at the Waldorf. Also compared to 5* hotels in London it seemed so cheap! This hotel just has a sort of feel to it, unrivaled by any other i can think of, that you get as your car draws up on Park Avenue, and one of the doormen in green opens the door for you and ushers you in.

Reviews.Title: “Suite Stay!”
Reviews.Author: traveler4k
Reviews.Content: OK. I took a lot of pictures of the suite that I stayed in in to submit to tripadvisor.com. First of all, I stayed in a "Landmark Luxury Suite". I have stayed at the Waldorf in the past and would suggest that you upgrade if you can, even to something larger than the standard. I will also primarily discuss this accommodation as a suite as it was relevant to my stay there, so if you want to read about this suite and possibly book it, stay with me on this. The hotel: I have stayed at The Plaza (see my review there) and The Waldorf in the past. This hotel is definitely far superior to the Plaza! Check-in was nice and quick. They advised me that I had VIP status but that really meant NOTHING! Check out was even better as you just call 69 from your extension and they instantly check you out and all you do is just leave your keys in the room. The lobby is opulent and grand, truly. The Waldorf is NYC's grand-dame and properly so. The suite: Guys, this suite will knock the socks off any girl! All my girlfriend kept saying was "Oh my God, honey". Incredible, especially for NYC. The suite had a HUGE living room and a nice king bedroom. All the cielings are high. It was tastefully furnished and as you can see from the pictures above (from my cell phone poor quality's cam) this suite is sweet! While it is worth the extra, the ONLY down-side is that there was no private dining area (but you could use the desk with two chairs in the living room). The ONLY other down-side: The televisions should be plasma and that would make this suite perfect! The layout: You enter into a beautiful and huge marble foyer with double door entry and small chandelier. On the right you have an entrance to a huge living room with a sofa, two plush chairs, an armoire, two end tables and a faux fireplace with two ottomans in fromt of it. The decor is tasteful. To the far left of the foyer: there is an entry to a full small kitchen closed with a door. This has a full fridge, toaster, cabinets, champagne/wine glasses, a dishwasher, toaster-oven, and a microwave. It was great to stop and bring back water, breakfast stuff and goodies without the inflated price of the mini bar charges! To the left of the foyer: The bedroom. The bedroom was large but simple. It had a nice king-sized bed, 2 chairs with a table between them, an armoir, two night stands, an ottoman and a chest with drawers. PRIVACY: After crossing the bedroom: The cool thing about this suite is the bedroom's privacy! The bedroom shares a wall with the dressing room to the south and the other wall is the living room to the north. That means that you have no neighbors at all while you sleep. The dressing room is great! This is a perfect suite for a long stay. The dressing room is a large bedroom-sized room that has 6 closets and storage on top for large luggage pieces. There is also a large electronic safe for valuables. It is equiped with a desk and chair, floor to cieling mirrors and a window to the outside and a chandelier. The bathroom: After crossing the dressing room, the bathroom is next. This was one of the coolest part of this suite. The bathroom was about 15 ft. by 15 ft. It had one sink with plenty of space on top (I am not sure why they did not make it a double sink). There is a seperate shower and a huge tub (without jets). The shower is equipped with 3 jets. There is a small peninsula where the toilet is enclosed but the toilet has no private door. Again, little things that are irrelevant but can perfect this suite. The bathroom also has a small chandelier. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by the Waldorf and actually the value that you can get on this type of regal accommodation! The view: As you can see it is nice. You get the north view of the stretch of Park Avenue. If you look west, you can see 50th Street and a glimpse of St. Patrick's Cathedral that is only a block away. You are extremely close to all Midtown Manhattan attractions. Times Square, Rockefeller Center, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Central Park, Grand Central and theaters are all within a 15 minute walk or less. I am a very picky traveler and like to stay at 5 star hotels. The Waldorf is easily a 4 and a half to 5 star experience. Would I reccommend the Waldorf=Astoria? ABSOLUTELY!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Hotel, made it a Fantastic Holiday”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel is fantastic, the location, the facilities, the staff, the cleanliness and the rooms are all well above average. We went to this hotel for my son’s 18th birthday from February 14th to February 20th and had a truly magical time. The hotel is expensive but you get a lot for your money, you get a landmark hotel in the center of Manhattan. The location of this hotel is unrivaled every tourist attraction is in close radius and there’s the Lexington avenue line subway station a block away, this is a great way to get around. The restaurants in the hotel are extremely good. The Bull and Bear is a once in a life time visit, the food may seem expensive but the quality is out of this world, you have to try the 24oz porterhouse steak its beautiful. Oscar’s restaurant is nice and the food is good quality, but is better for breakfast rather than evening meal, but be warned it gets very busy in a morning. When we visited the hotel we stopped in a one-bedroom suit, which was very lush. There were two bathrooms both encased in marble and beautifully presented with towels that felt like new everyday. The beds feel like your sleeping on a cloud, without a doubt the comfiest bed I’ve ever slept on. The lounge was comfortable with a sofa, chair, TV cabinet with mini bar and desk. Our room had fantastic views north over Park Avenue. The window roller blinds can be tricky to operate! Every weekday morning you get a free USA today newspaper delivered to your room, in your room there is complimentary coffee making facilities and the coffee is replaced everyday complimentary. The free toiletries in the bathrooms are replaced everyday if only used once and are Neutrogena. If you want to be truly impressed ask for a tour of the hotel we were lucky enough to ask one of the managers. The tour is very interesting and the manager was very funny who took us for the tour. The silver corridor is very impressive which leads to the main ballroom which will take your breath away, the chandelier is extremely impressive. We we’re lucky enough to be taken into the Waldorf Towers and taken into the President Suit which every US president has stopped in, this suit is beautifully appointed but to be truly in awe ask to visit the Royal Suit. This suit is huge, the lounge is gorgeous with two clear and blue chandeliers each valued at over $1 million. There are some nice shops in the hotel but be warned you may find them expensive. The jeweler, Celini has some very nice sparkly diamonds but is very very expensive! The Park Avenue lobby is very impressive with a very nice mosaic depicting the circle of life. You will always see a maid cleaning this beautiful lobby. The hotel may be old but has been restored and maintained at a very high standard. I cannot find where other people have got negative reviews from. The staff are very attentive and polite, one evening our power was tripped but within 2 minutes of phoning reception the problem was corrected. I loved this hotel and when I next visit New York City there is no doubt I will be stopping at the Waldorf Astoria.

Reviews.Title: “A classic...”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Waldorf for 5 nights in March 05 and can not fault this hotel in any way. The staff were excellent from the moment we arrived. As we were staying for 5 nights the receptionist upgraded us from a standard to an executive room free of charge and we were checked in early and our bags brought to our room within about 15 minutes. The room was newly renovated with 2 extremely comfortable beds and all the usual amenities including bathrobes and (free) coffee making facilities. It was very clean and well maintained and the hotel provided a twice daily maid service. The rooms are not the same standard as you would find in maybe the Ritz or the Mandarin Oriental but I would certainly rate them as an excellent 4* standard and are at least half the price of the Ritz etc. Our room was on the 12th floor and had a view of Lexington Avenue and the W Hotel across the street. I wasn't particularly bothered by the traffic noise but if you are a light sleeper I would recommend a room on a high floor as New York is the city that never sleeps and therefore can be noisy! The public spaces are unbelievably beautiful and are so spacious that even when the numerous conferences and events are taking place it does not feel crowded and we never had any trouble with queues for taxis/reception etc. Everyone should stay at the Waldorf at least once in their life-it is a glamorous, truly New York experience and I would not hesitate to recommend it. A 5* stay!!

Reviews.Title: “It was nice in the fifties - that was 50 years ago!!!”
Reviews.Author: DrBob5
Reviews.Content: The hotels is in a decent location. You can walk to many local tourist areas and so ends the positive attributes of the place. The place is a hotel from another time. Check -in was promised to be at 12 during the reservation, but was not till after 3pm. The room was small and faced a air conditioner vent. The bathroom was also tiny any had no ventilation fan!!!! The concierge didn't know that pastis a trendy spot in the meatpacking district didn't require reservations and tried to send us to a Friday's instead. Overall a weak experience. Total bill was 350$. I'd rather stayed at the Hudson or the Marriot Marqios. Never again.

Reviews.Title: “Wouldn't recommend it”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Have just returned from a three night stay, first night we were put in a dreadful room next to a machinery room which kept us awake all night. On complaining we were moved to a much nicer room with a better view of Park Ave - however the guy in the next suite was very noisy and the workmen started in the street outside at 12:00am and carried on working until 4:30am. On our third and final night our neighbour decided to have a bit of a party upon returning to the room at 3:00am - admittedly this wasn't the hotel's fault but it did take them an hour to get him to turn the noise down. This trully is the city that never sleeps! We found ourselves sleeping in the mornings instead of the night! The hotel did however offer us a free nights stay in an upgraded room - unprompted - which we won't be using as we don't plan to use. For the price I think it is over-rated and depending on its name - a warning watch out for the coffee in the room - they charge for this!

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed at the Waldorf”
Reviews.Author: ResearchBeforeTravel
Reviews.Content: Our room was quite cramped and extremely dark. The bathroom had been nicely remodeled, but we were very uncomfortable in the rest. Also, there were no plugs for the coffee maker or anything else. The hotel had already employed an overstuffed multiplug for a lamp, fax, modem, etc. The rooms in the towers are larger and brighter, though not all have completely refurbished bathrooms.

Reviews.Title: “NYC Landmark”
Reviews.Author: baileypie79
Reviews.Content: I have always heard about the Waldorf being a native New Yorker living only an hour from NYC. I saw a deal to staying at the hotel and thought what a great deal to stay at a NYC landmark. Anyhow, I first booked the Waldorf before seeing the reviews for the hotel. However, before I went I did see the reviews and was nervous about getting some old dirty hotel room. However, upon arriving at the hotel me and my boyfriend arrive into a grand entrance and proceed to the reception desk. Upon check-in we were assisted by a friendly front desk women in a very timely manner. We then proceed to our room on the 19th floor and entered our room. The room was smaller then an average size room at a normal hotel but probably in NYC standards it was about right. The room had the usual the tv, bed, and dresser and the not normally in your room a fax machine and mini-bar. Also, the hotel doesn't have your standard radios it has bose wave radio which was really a nice touch.The mini-bar in my opinion was really over price but hey if you feel like spending $ 5.50 on a 12oz soda then go ahead. The bed was nicely made with 3 pillows prefectly placed on the bed. The bathroom was the nicest bathroom of any hotel I have ever stayed at in my life. The bed was very comfortable to sleep in as well. Also, the hotel has room service which I would have chosen but I really cant paid over like $50 for 2 people for breakfast when normally at most I spend $15. Anyhow, the hotel lost a star because the fire alarm went off in the middle of the night for like 20 minutes and then a message kept coming on to stay in your rooms. Also, the other thing to was even though the room was on the 19th floor I could still hear the cars on the street. However, overall this hotel is worth a stay at least one time in your life since it is such a legendary NYC landmark.

Reviews.Title: “loved it”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Like many others I was concerned about other reviews. We had a King Mini Suite on the 20th floor. It was huge with long hallway separating living room and bedroom and two bathrooms. Our view was of the Chrysler Building though french doors onto a terrace type area. The maid service was top quality with our bed being turned back each evening. We ate in the Bull and Bear and the steak was excellent, portions were typically American so there were lots of leftovers. We were typical Brits and could not ask for the leftovers in a box like the natives did! The public areas were magnificant - only one corridor let the place down in the parts we saw. All staff were very professional and friendly. We would definitely recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Great first time visit”
Reviews.Author: Nell1465
Reviews.Content: After reading the reviews on the website I was a little anxious about staying at the Waldorf Astoria. However overall I had a fantastic time and can recommend the hotel to first-timers like myself. I stayed at the hotel from March 3-6 2005 with my wife. We had a corner room on the 6th floor overlooking St Barts. A little noisy (air-con unit outside room) so try and get a room as high as possible (but I guess that is a problem with city hotels). Room & hotel in excellent condition. King bed was very comfy. Staff were very polite and helpful. Ordered room service a couple of times and was very pleased with service and quality. Would definitely consider staying again.

Reviews.Title: “Waldorf May be Misleading to Some”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I agree with the person who reviewed the hotel and identified some excellent points. The Waldorf, although a nice hotel and amazing that it was constructed in the late 1800's is not a boutique hotel. If you want a truly unique experience I would suggest staying at its sister hotel...the Waldorf Towers. I do think the website for the Waldorf...if you have arrived there through the Hilton website is very misleading. Nowhere within the site does it mention that the Towers are a hotel within a hotel and occupy the 28 through 42 floors of the Waldorf Astoria. Hotel guest can easily book a suite...but to only realize at time of check-in that your room will not be higher than the 27th floor. To be fair, this little fact is mentioned...only after you manage to look at the Towers website, but it is not clear on the Waldorf site...in addition, the pictures shown on the Waldorf site are their best suites on the 27th floor facing Park Ave. To conclude, be ware as one guest mentioned...you pay for what you get. During the Winter months a one night stay at the Waldorf is surprisingly low rate of 300 per night, while the Towers smallest room (800sq ft) will set you back 800 per night....to compare...a Waldorf luxury suite is only 400 per night while the Towers Empire Room is 5000 per night.

Reviews.Title: “Old school hotel - a must stay!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Having read the reviews on this site before we travelled I was extremely concerned about staying at the hotel and tried very hard to change my booking to another hotel. As I stayed over Valentines week it was not possible - so hoped that the Waldorf would be better than the reviews. And it was! I think the thing to remember is that this is an old school hotel, it was built in the 1930's (ish) and is not a modern hotel. However it is a beautiful art deco building and a New York classic- so you won't find minamalist furniture and uber cool surrondings but you will find a true art deco experience. The hotel is huge which is why there are so many business travellers there but they didn't bother us at all. The staff were friendly and polite to us at all times. The lobby and entrance areas are a must see - they don't make hotels like this anymore and much nicer than the Plaza! Our room was a little on the small side but what do you need a huge room for anyway?? We had the most comfy King size bed I've ever stayed in with beautiful decor throughout (again not at all minimalist but tasteful chinz), a big wardrobe (enough for a week's worth of clothes) and a small ish bathroom. All were clean and well kept. One point worth noting is that New York is not a quiet city!!!!! Our room was on the Lexington Ave side of the hotel and was noisy but you get used to it and I think that you would suffer the same problem in any NYC hotel - so light sleepers be warned.
